Tasks.Task Description: Gather detailed requirements for storage capacity, performance, redundancy, and access patterns. Identify the data types and workloads that will use Azure Blob Storage.
Design the storage architecture, including the selection of storage tiers (Hot, Cool, Archive), redundancy options (LRS, GRS, ZRS), and integration with existing systems.
Create a new Azure Storage Account in the Azure portal or using Azure CLI/PowerShell. Configure the account with the appropriate performance and redundancy settings.
Set up blob containers within the storage account. Define naming conventions and access levels (private, blob, or container).
Enable security features such as Azure AD authentication, Shared Access Signatures (SAS), and encryption at rest using Microsoft-managed or customer-managed keys.
Configure virtual network service endpoints or private endpoints to restrict access to the storage account from specific networks.
Set up monitoring and alerting using Azure Monitor and Storage Analytics. Configure alerts for metrics such as capacity usage, transaction rates, and error rates.
Perform performance testing to validate throughput, latency, and scalability. Ensure the storage account meets the required performance benchmarks.
Set up backup and recovery solutions using Azure Backup or third-party tools. Define recovery point objectives (RPO) and recovery time objectives (RTO).
Document the storage account configuration, including access policies, security settings, and monitoring setup. Share the documentation with relevant stakeholders.
Provide training to the operations team on managing and troubleshooting Azure Blob Storage, including using Azure portal, CLI, and PowerShell.
Ensure the storage setup complies with organizational and regulatory requirements. Conduct regular audits to verify compliance and security postures.
Regularly review storage usage and costs. Optimize costs by moving data to appropriate storage tiers and deleting unused data.
